title: Metaphor and Irony from the Perspective of Experimental Pragmatics - 2024
description:
The course targets special issues in the psychology of communication fundamental for approaches in the study of education sciences and culture. It specifically addresses issues of cognitive and conceptual development and language development, along with the abilities of social cognition and its role in the unfolding of conversational and discourse skills.
The course is a realization of the collaboration with the University of Cagliari in the EDUC framework, the European Union’s online digital educational project, hence, a considerable part of the course will be based on shared, joint classes with the university of Cagliari.
The topics addressed help and back up the understanding of topics popular for MA Thesis papers like Bilingualism, Language development, Atypical development, Dyslexia, and the Psycholinguistics of idiomatic language use and understanding.

title: Conference - Introduction to research ethics and scientific integrity (French)
description:
The half-day study session has an introductory function, demonstrating the value to researchers of critical and problematic reflection on research ethics and scientific integrity. Its aim is to raise doctoral students' awareness by outlining the main issues and concepts.

Description
Morning programme:
- Introduction to research ethics and scientific integrity led by Mathieu Rouault, Grand Labo science journalist.
- Lecture on legal and moral ethics by Jean-Marcel PIRIOU, research engineer at the CNRM (Centre National de Recherches Météorologiques), CNRS / Météo-France.
He provides training in ‘ethics and scientific integrity’ for doctoral students at the Toulouse Doctoral School. In 2012, he published the book ‘Happiness here and now’, which looks at the link between ethics, law and morality, and other notions of general philosophy. The lecture will be followed by a 30-minute discussion.
Presentation
In the first part, he will give examples of ethical, societal or research problems (debates on animal experimentation, localisation and 5G, plagiarism in research, tensions over co-authorship or the anteriority of results, the societal role of whistleblowers, etc.). He will then document the links and differences between ethics, law and morality: definitions, examples. He will discuss their causal links, and how ethical reflection drives the development of laws and morals. It will look at ethics in history. And he will give examples of ethical dilemmas in research, which will be an opportunity to present a central method in ethical reflection: identifying the values at stake, then sorting them out, and stressing the importance of an open and consensual debate on them (ethics committees). He will use examples to illustrate the link between values and virtues. He will also review scientific truth and its link with the ethical approach. He will define scientific ethics and integrity, and give examples. The final session will focus on the link between ethics and self-confidence, and how the ethical approach is liberating.
- Round table: Ethics and scientific integrity officer in higher education establishments: role and missions
The issues of scientific ethics and integrity are becoming increasingly important in the conduct of research, as well as in the publication of research results and the promotion of research. This concern must therefore emerge right from the research training that constitutes doctoral studies. In addition to the major ethical principles that prohibit plagiarism and the publication of fraudulent results, ethical issues arise throughout the research process, in the day-to-day work of the researcher, with the collection and use of data. This varies from one scientific discipline to another, but they are all involved in one way or another: protection of individuals, protection of digital data, animal rights and environmental protection, etc. In addition to the vigilance that researchers must maintain in their practice, they may also need to obtain authorisations from bodies dedicated to these aspects, which will be discussed in the course of this half-day training session.

title: MOOC - Research integrity in scientific professions
description:
This Mooc is available in French and in English

Objectifs
- Adopt a critical approach
- Support the requirements of research integrity
- Inform about research integrity issues
- Alert you to the mechanisms that can lead to scientific misconducts
- Encourage you to develop a sense of responsibility and conduct yourself in a spirit of scientific integrity

Descriptif

Since the Singapore Declaration on Scientific Integrity in 2010, the international scientific community has been mobilizing to ensure that the methodological and ethical requirements of research are more clearly asserted, in a context where the race for novelty and the introduction of a reinforced competitive logic are multiplying the risks of drift. In addition, stricter regulations and the challenges of social responsibility mean that the fundamental principles of scientific integrity must be understood and embraced.
France's various research organizations have stepped up their initiatives, and their convergence led to the signing of the Charter of Ethics for Research Professions by France Universités (Association of Universities and Higher Education and Research Establishments) and the main organizations in January 2015. Following the report submitted by Prof. Pierre Corvol in 2016, "Bilan et propositions de mise en œuvre de la charte nationale d'intégrité scientifique", several decisions were taken, including :

- doctoral schools must ensure that doctoral students receive training in ethics and scientific integrity,
- establishments have appointed a scientific integrity referent,
- a French Office of Scientific Integrity (OFIS) was set up in 2017 within the Haut Conseil de l'évaluation de la recherche et de l'enseignement supérieur (Hcéres). 

This mobilization was reinforced at the end of 2021 by the publication of a legislative decree on compliance with scientific integrity requirements by public establishments and foundations contributing to the public research service. This text introduces into the law a definition of scientific integrity and the obligation for establishments to ensure the awareness and training of their staff and students in respecting the requirements of scientific integrity.

Committed to this issue since 2012 with the adoption of a charter, the University of Bordeaux has, in partnership with the CPU, COMETS-CNRS, INSERM and INRA, developed the training course on scientific integrity that we are offering you.

title: Gender and careers (French)
description:
Objectives

On average, women now have higher levels of education than men. However, they find it harder to get a job, are more likely to find themselves in precarious situations, are often paid less and have fewer opportunities for promotion, including in academia. For example, the salary of a male manager is five times higher than it was at the start of his career, while that of a female manager is only 2.7 times higher (INSEE 2010). This situation can be explained by a number of factors: the burden of domestic tasks and bringing up children, lower professional ambitions, male solidarity, less assertiveness, dedication to the company without sufficient recognition of the work done, etc.

The aims of this course are:

-  to help doctoral students identify the various factors that can limit their ability to advance and to give them the means to avoid having to put up with a situation,
- examine the impact of male domination at university and how it relates to other forms of discrimination,
- learn about policies to promote gender equality at university and their possible limitation

Course description
1.  Exposure of socio-historical obstacles (in particular the "glass ceiling" that women still encounter in their professional careers, including in academia, and the illusion of equality already there and its confusion with gender diversity),

2.    Legislation, legal instruments and resources to counter this situation.

3.    Interactions based on situations experienced by doctoral students.
prerequisites: All PhD candidates with 3rd year given priority

title: Writing Across Cultures (English Academic Writing II) - Winter 2024/25
description:
#### Learning objectives

Taking the UNESCO working paper "Intercultural Competence: Conceptual and Operational Framework" (Leeds-Hurwitzand Stenou, 2013) as a springboard, we investigate the meaning and relevance of intercultural competence in today's world. Students then research and write about a topic of their choosing that is related to intercultural competence. Exercises that develop students' peer review skills will help them to identify and correct errors in their peers' and in their own writing. We view writing squarely as a process and consequently do portfolio work over the course of the semester. The semester culminates in a short presentation of the students' essays.
We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate stating 90 hours as workload, equivalent to 3 ECTS). In both cases, students will be issued an EDUC certificate. **Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.** Please see "More Info" for the course time, expected outcomes, and requirements.

title: INTERFACE: English Oral Proficiency and Intercultural Competence - Winter 2024/25
description:
#### Learning objectives
INTERFACE (INTERculural proFiciency and orAl Competence in English) is a model project of social online teaching and learning. Since 2020, it has brought together about 300  B.A. English and B.Ed. English students from the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel) and provides these students with opportunities to experience virtual collaboration. The course instructors in Germany and Israel (originally from the USA, South Africa, and Great Britain) focus on improving students’ oral proficiency in English (accuracy, fluency, pronunciation), and participants have been able to attain a high proficiency in the main communicative language competences as outlined in the CEFR.
What is more, INTERFACE presents a form of didactic modeling, which is especially important for future educators. Student participants are encouraged to take an active role in this online project and thus have have a degree of autonomy (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “4. Target group-specific teaching”). They can select which digital tools work best for them, reflect on alternative assessment models (tasks and rubrics), and decide what constitutes authentic learning and a safe online learning environment. In doing so, they grow to understand the importance of collaboration and innovation. By working in English with speakers of Arabic, Hebrew, German, and other languages, the students question their ideas of the “Other” and grow to embrace diversity.  Furthermore, the project also prepares the students with skills for life and the workforce, such as flexibility and adaptability, social and cross-cultural skills, and accountability and responsibility (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “2. Career orientation and personal development”). 
**We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (for no ECTS points) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate stating 90 hours as workload, equivalent to 3 ECTS).** In both cases, students will be issued an EDUC certificate. **Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.** 
Please see "More Info" for the course time, expected outcomes, and requirements.

The goal of the course is meant to enhance MUNI students’ intercultural communication competence and improve their communication skills in French and in English by exchanging with students from foreign universities through virtual exchanges.

- to dispel, by working together on common projects, the self-centered perceptions of one’s cultural environments and contexts
- to develop openness and positive attitudes towards other cultures
- to develop plurilinguistic and pluricultural competencies

#### Learning Outcomes
After completion of the course, the students:
- will understand key concepts of intercultural communication
- will develop cultural self-awareness and awareness of other cultures
- will be able to recognize and analyze common barriers to effective intercultural communication
- will improve their listening skills and effective communication skills when engaging in discussions and project work with students from other universities

On average, women now have higher levels of education than men. However, they find it harder to get a job, are more likely to find themselves in precarious situations, are often paid less and have fewer opportunities for promotion, including in academia. For example, the salary of a male manager is five times higher than it was at the start of his career, while that of a female manager is only 2.7 times higher (INSEE 2010). This situation can be explained by a number of factors: the burden of domestic tasks and bringing up children, lower professional ambitions, male solidarity, less assertiveness, dedication to the company without sufficient recognition of the work done, etc.

The aims of this course are to:

- Help doctoral students identify the various factors that can limit their ability

- Advance and to give them the means to avoid having to put up with a situation.

- Examine the impact of male domination at university and how it relates to other forms of discrimination.

- Learn about policies to promote gender equality at university and their possible limitations.

 


Objectives

The aim of this module is to acquire the following skills:

- Identify the different types of harassment: moral harassment, sexual harassment, discriminatory harassment, and the forms they can take in higher education and research,

- Understand how harassment works, the effects on the victims and the strategies of the perpetrators,

- Be familiar with the legal and regulatory texts governing these issues, in particular the obligations of higher education and research establishments, and know how to use them,

- Be familiar with the various avenues of recourse: non-contentious or contentious (disciplinary or criminal),

- Know how to react to a situation of harassment and identify the roles of possible contacts, both internal and external.



PROGRAMME :

-  Introductory quiz,
-  Post-it workshop: harassment and its effects (based on trainees' experiences),
-  Identifying harassment (moral, discriminatory, sexual): legal and sociological framework 
-  Knowing how to prevent and react: the establishment's obligations (prevention / support / treatment), avenues of appeal, places and resource persons in Brittany,
-  How to react as an active witness and prevent harassment: workshop with role play,
-  Conclusion and evaluation

title: EDUC Gap Semester - 2025/2026 Academic Year
description:
#### Learning objectives

The EDUC Gap Semester is a mobility programme that allows students to compose their own curriculum by choosing different fields of study at another partner university for one semester or a full academic year.
It is a unique opportunity for students to not only have a break from their current studies but also to explore the possibilities of alternative or complementary subjects, courses, and programmes that allow them to develop new knowledge and personalise their CV.

The EDUC Gap year allows students to open up to the wold by living and studying elsewhere in Europe, improving their language skills, and developing new soft skills. The EDUC alliance considers this mobility as a tool for developing a European sense of belonging and an asset for the social and professional success of students.
For details concerning courses attended by the student aforementioned, please refer to the official Transcript of Records.


#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is a physical mobility of 1 semester in order to study other subjects than your initial training.
An interruption in your studies at your home university. Students are treated as exchange students at the receiving university, but this mobility, unlike an Erasmus+ mobility, does not count towards their degree (*except for MU students). It is an additional semester.

Students must select and attend a number of courses equivalent to 30 ECTS credits for one semester.


#### Scholarships
Students in this program receive an EDUC mobility scholarship from their home university to finance their mobility at the partner university. The amount of the scholarship varies depending on the home university and the destination.
